title: 20250207 - attempt 1 - Deep research -  LLM Historical Research Protocol

parts:
I need your help with crafting a prompt for deep research.

Here's our current notes document:

% Impact of LLM on historical studies

What specific queries could we plausibly send to deep research to test this protocol? 

We also have a paper in progress, looking to be a literature review of the lifecycle of research software used by archaeologists, historians, corpus linguists, and and the historical sciences. We need to get a corpus of software projects by exploring the open literature (i.e. in SoftwareX, Internet Archaeology, and PLoS1) (The Thesius ship article)

Beyond that, we want to build upon the case studies by Breen:
```The leading AI models are now good historians
... in specific domains. Three case studies with GPT-4o, o1, and Claude Sonnet 3.5, and what they mean
Benjamin Breen
Jan 23, 2025

This is a post I began writing last year, but several things got in the way: above all, paternity leave. But also my own increasing dismay at the ways that LLMs were being used by students in the classroom. Ask anyone you know in education: ChatGPT has been a disaster when it comes to facilitating student cheating and — perhaps even more troubling — contributing to a general malaise among undergraduates. It’s not just that students are submitting entirely AI-written assignments. They are also (I suspect) relying on AI-generated answers far more comprehensively, not just in their homework but in their daily lives. This has a kind of flattening effect. I’m not alone in noticing the increasingly sameness of student responses to course material. LLMs, which are exquisitely well-tuned machines for finding the median viewpoint on a given issue, are surely contributing to it.

In other words, it’s clear that we will have a turbulent period of change as we figure out how to fit these new capabilities into our existing structures of education. For that reason, I’m not quite as optimistic about how this will go as I was when I wrote this back in fall of 2023:

How to use generative AI for historical research
Benjamin Breen
·
14 November 2023
How to use generative AI for historical research
Last week, OpenAI announced what it calls “GPTs” — AI agents built on GPT-4 that can be given unique instructions and knowledge, allowing them to be customized for specific use cases.

Read full story
But that’s not the whole story. The headaches that LLMs have caused in the classroom are (I believe) more than counterbalanced by what they can offer as tools for research and self-directed learning. For this reason, I’m now even more optimistic about the long-term impact and utility of AI tools for historical research — and, by extension, for other forms of text or image-based research.

I’m told that OpenAI’s newish o1 model is genuinely helpful and creative when it comes to thinking through open problems in the sciences, especially fields like biology, physics, and medicine. It remains to be seen if it will facilitate any actual breakthroughs. But what’s clear to me is that both o1 and the older GPT-4o model are now almost shockingly good at several core historical skills, and that’s a good thing.

Type your email...
Subscribe

Case study #1: Transcribing and translating early modern Italian
Here, for instance, is how GPT-4o handles the task of transcribing this block of text from Urbano Monte’s world map, written in 16th century Italian cursive handwriting:


This is basically perfect, with the exception of a few small errors (like “disegnato” instead of “dissegnata” in the second line).1

Granted, Monte had unusually legible handwriting, but even “easy” early modern paleography like this is still the sort of thing that requires days or weeks of training to get the hang of.

Likewise, although my knowledge of Italian is not great, I can read it well enough to confirm that the translation it offers is good enough to use for research:

Described by Urbano Monte, a Milanese gentleman, and designed by himself
in sixty tables, graduated in length and width, according to the geography of many reliable authors, both ancient and modern.
With explanations for all the tables, particularly regarding the nature of the regions,
and the most notable things found within them. These tables can be combined and taught to form a complete world map in a circular flat form. Before these, for greater understanding and the satisfaction of students, there are two books: the first deals with many natural matters concerning the nature of the world, and the other is distinguished by a full discourse on all the terms and rules of geography.
It includes an extensive table of ancient names of provinces, cities, seas, rivers, and other elements clarified with their modern equivalents. And many other tables and notes of beautiful speculations and necessities, which anyone reading them will be able to understand. Finally, after some discussions on the eclipses of the sun and moon, and some of their effects, and other matters regarding the quality and quantity of the winds, as well as how to trace a navigational compass and how to understand and use a navigational chart, two detailed indices are provided in this book: one for the tables and chapters, and the other for the most notable contents of the book.

This was provided by a custom GPT I made, the Historian’s Friend, which is a variant of GPT-4o that has a system prompt with some specific directions relating to historical text transcription, analysis, etc. So when asked to provide “historical context” for a translation like this, it knows that it is supposed to cite only the most relevant academic sources.

An excerpt:

Early Modern Cartography and Cosmography

Themes: The creation of large-scale world maps in the early modern era reflects the integration of empirical observation, humanist scholarship, and the legacy of medieval cosmographical traditions. Urbano Monte’s emphasis on combining ancient and modern sources aligns with the Renaissance ideal of synthesizing classical wisdom with contemporary discoveries.

Notable Works for Context:

Brotton, Jerry. A History of the World in Twelve Maps (2012): Examines how maps from different periods reflect cultural and political ideologies.

Harley, J.B., and David Woodward. The History of Cartography (1987–2007): A multi-volume work exploring cartography’s development, including Renaissance mapmaking.

Renaissance Humanism and Classical Continuity

The text’s mention of “ancient and modern authors” reflects Renaissance humanism’s preoccupation with rediscovering and reconciling classical sources with contemporary knowledge.

Key Texts:

Grafton, Anthony. Defenders of the Text (1991): Investigates how Renaissance scholars revived classical knowledge through new methodologies.

Burke, Peter. The Renaissance Sense of the Past (1969): Examines how Renaissance scholars navigated the tension between reverence for antiquity and contemporary innovation.

… and so on.

The upshot: this is pretty much exactly what I would provide for a student trying to learn more on this topic, except it adds texts I should know about, but don’t (for instance, it recommended I read a newish and interesting looking book called The Commerce of Cartography — a genuinely useful tip). Elsewhere in the full response, GPT-4o suggested books which I hadn’t considered as being relevant to understanding a specific early modern map, but which, on reflection, actually are (for instance, Peter Burke book on the Renaissance sense of the past).

Does this replace the actual reading required? Not at all. What it does is aggregate an expert-level knowledge of a topic. Even a year ago, when I requested further reading on a topic, ChatGPT would either invent fake sources or recommend terrible ones (like a History Channel website). That is no longer the case.

Case study #2: making sense of a strange 18th century medical text
OpenAI’s o1 is the current reigning champ of AI models for reasoning and general-purpose thinking. In my testing, that has proven true when it comes to historical analysis, too. I picked a fairly readable but highly unusual historical source from 18th century Mexico to test it. The following image was provided with no context, just a request to transcribe, translate, and offer a detailed historical and iconographic analysis.


A page from an 18th century Mexican compendium of medical recipes. Credit: the Wellcome Library.
First off, how cool is this book? It’s a page from a manuscript of medical recipes written in 1770s Mexico and now held at the excellent Wellcome Library in London. This is my own photograph from a research trip, but the Wellcome has now fully digitized the book, which you can browse here.

Second, try reading the first lines. Can you make out the words?

o1 gave me the following as a transcription and translation:

Cons[ulta Médi]ca de D[on] Juan Batista Proco[p]io…

Section Title: “Fiebre Catharral”

No se trata en esta consulta de dar la explicación poética de los accidentes, de que se compone la curación, sólo sí de los auxilios, y régimen, que pueden servir a vencerlos con seguridad y brevedad. Ninguno debe arriesgarse a dilatar su curación, en cualquier enfermedad, que le sobrevenga (porque es el camino del peligro) antes de solicitar luego el remedio; por ser más fácil la reducción de los males en los primeros instantes, que cuando han cobrado cuerpo. Los más trabajadillos, fiebres purpurinas, y casi pestilenciales, que se padecen en las Yndias, suelen sacar su origen de las fiebres, y, por mal curadas, o por descuidadas en los principios. No puede ser mayor, ni más pernicioso el error de los Médicos en este particular …

“Medical Consultation of Don Juan Batista Procopio…”

Section Title: “Catarrhal Fever”

Main Text:

“In this consultation, it is not our purpose to provide a poetic explanation of the accidents that make up the cure, but rather to describe the aids and regimen that can conquer them with safety and brevity. No one should risk delaying his cure, in any ailment whatsoever that may befall him (since that is the path of danger), but should instead seek the remedy at once; for it is easier to reduce the harm in the earliest moments, before it has taken root. The worst cases—purplish fevers and those almost pestilential that one encounters in the Indies—often originate in fevers that were improperly treated or neglected at the beginning. There can be no greater nor more pernicious error on the part of physicians in this matter …”

There are, again, a few errors here: it should be “explicación phisica” [physical explanation] not “poetic explanation” in the first line, for instance.2 In this barebones task, I don’t see that o1 is any different from the older GPT-4o model.

Where it shines is in thinking through potential approaches to understanding a text, and also explaining ambiguities.

For instance, here is part of the “iconographic analysis” I asked it for:

This manuscript leaf—judging by its style of calligraphy, Spanish-language text, and references to illnesses “en las Yndias”—almost certainly dates to the Spanish colonial period (potentially the late 17th or early 18th century). The elaborate headings, featuring anthropomorphic suns, serpentine or zoomorphic letters, and the whimsical figure standing beneath the scrollwork, are reminiscent of the flourishing calligraphic tradition in both Spain and the viceroyalties of the Americas during that era. The human figure appears centrally framed by swirling cartouches, suggesting that the artist or scribe wanted to highlight either the author (Don Juan Batista Procopio) or a representative “patient” figure—possibly to symbolize the subject of the medical consultation.

Visual Motifs and Their Possible Meanings

Sun-Faces: The iconography of the sun with a human face was widespread in early modern Iberia and its colonies, often symbolizing enlightenment or divine illumination, but it could also simply be a decorative flourish referencing classical or alchemical imagery.

Serpentine Lettering: The large letter “C” or “S” that coils around the top might allude to the serpent as a medical symbol (thinking of the Rod of Asclepius in classical medicine). Alternatively, it might be purely ornamental.

Human Figure: The small, full-length man in breeches at the center is depicted with care: his stance, attire, and shading could suggest a 17th-century or early 18th-century fashion typical of either a Spanish gentleman or a colonial administrator. The heart or medallion on his chest might be purely decorative, or it could hint at medical knowledge (the seat of the humors) or at a badge of office.

Not bad!

And by the way… what is that “heart or medallion” on the figure’s chest, anyway?


I suspect it’s actually a physician holding (in his right hand) a portable medical chest, and in his left, a urine flask. But what strikes me here is not that the model guessed wrong — it’s that it even noticed such a small detail, and drew attention to it. I mention this one small detail because, to be honest, I had failed to notice it myself.

Although this is not exactly a breakthrough finding, it is quite indicative of the sorts of ways that generative AI can help us do research going forward. It is another, wholly alien pair of “eyes” on a given problem or domain, and that altered perspective can be helpful, even (or especially) when it’s wrong.

Case study #3: generating new historical interpretations
For a final test — comparing OpenAI’s o1 model with Anthropic’s Sonnet 3.5 — I tried giving both a copy and paste from my notes for my new book project, Ghosts of the Machine Age, which is a group biography about the transformations of science and technology in the 1880s through 1910s. Two of the main characters are Francis Galton and William James, so I figured I’d “feed” these two AI models with some direct quotes from James’ letters and works relating to Galton, and then ask it to analyze them, with an emphasis on exploring new paths forward and novel research directions. I also asked it to “perform metacognitive reflection on research paths.”

The results are too long to copy out here, but you can read o1’s full response at this link.

Here’s an excerpt which highlights how o1 leaves behind a “stream of consciousness” (a term William James coined, as it happens) in a sidebar.


Hitherto, it had seemed to me that Sonnet 3.5 was the best AI overall for historical thinking, but o1 clearly thinks at a higher level about the possible uses and interpretations of historical sources.

Here’s the o1 at left and Claude Sonnet at right, both attempting to self-reflect on further paths forward for research on the topic of James and Galton:


Claude was hung up on its own potential flaws, whereas o1 — far more confidently, and far more like a real human historian — began thinking through some legitimate options for archival research to learn more. There is nothing revolutionary here, but for the first time I can see this as a potentially useful interlocutor: someone I can talk to about a new set of ideas or a new research direction.

It’s also interesting to see what happens if you prompt the same o1 model to do something unusual or boundary-pushing. For instance, here is part of what it generated when II asked it for “the most creative, boundary-pushing, or innovative historical arguments or analyses you can formulate based on the sources I provided”:

One could easily read William James’s ambivalent reflections on Galton—and by extension on Pearson and “statistical modernity”—as a polite but profound philosophical revolution in the making. Beneath James’s genial skepticism toward “Galtonian circulars” or “scientific logic” lies a startling proposition: what if the cardinal sin of modern scientific culture isn’t “unreliability,” but rather a flattening of human complexity into numbers that cannot capture the thrumming pulse of individuality?

It then came up with no less than eight different original frameworks for pursuing historical arguments based on these sources.

Here’s one:

1. The Anti-Panopticon of Consciousness
Argument: Galton’s approach—and Pearson’s broader “logical” method—anticipates a kind of proto-panoptic gaze, one that tries to glean “the truth” of humanity from the vantage of big-sample, statistical uniformity. James, however, insists that genuine knowledge of the mind should be irreducibly private and personal. From that vantage, the “self” is not an object but the seat of moral and epistemic agency—capable of forging new truths through introspection and creative will. In effect, James is forging a blueprint for an “anti-panopticon”: consciousness as an irreducible interior fortress that refuses to be pinned down by the numeric lens.

Why This Is Radical: Where Michel Foucault (in Discipline and Punish) identified panopticism as an architecture of total visibility, James’s call for introspective humility subverts that architecture. In this reading, James is the stealth theoretician of privacy in an age obsessed with “averages,” “curves,” and “normal distributions.” Rather than reading James and Galton as simply a difference in philosophical style, one might interpret them as building rival “political technologies” of the mind—Galton’s, to classify and control; James’s, to keep an interior realm off-limits to all but the self.

The above excerpt is… good. I almost want to say depressingly good, because at first glance, it’s fairly close to the level of analysis that I’m currently at with my book project, and it was generated in exactly 5 seconds.

But no: I don’t fear replacement by this kind of thing.

After all (he said, pleadingly) consciousness really is an irreducible interior fortress that refuses to be pinned down by the numeric lens (really, it is!)

Share

Summing up
I realize that some people reading this will probably be thinking around this point “why write a book about William James and the history of science, if the next OpenAI model is likely going to be able to auto-generate a decent approximation of it?”

The answer is that I genuinely do believe that human consciousness and creativity is both an end in itself and a source of value in itself — not something that can be replaced, just as no single human researcher or writer, no matter how brilliant, can replace the work of all the others who may be less skillful or knowledgeable. Especially because it seems to me unlikely that the generic-ness, the median-ness, of LLMs will appreciably change, even as they get shockingly better at meta-reflection and creative thinking.

After all: when you get down to it, o1 talking about a panopticon and Foucault in the above snippet is very, very similar to what a first year history PhD student might produce.

This makes sense: 2025 is, after all, being hailed as the year that PhD-level AI agents will flourish. I can personally report that, in the field of history, we’re already there.

But the architecture of these models, the data that feeds them and the human training the guides them, all converges on the median. The supposedly “boundary-pushing” ideas it generated were all pretty much what a class of grad students would come up with — high level and well-informed, but predictable.

Will that change in the next year or two? Clearly, many people in the AI field and adjacent to it think so. But I favor the possibility that there is an inherent upper limit in what these models can do once they approach the “PhD level,” if we want to call it that. In fact, that’s exactly why I’m writing a book about William James and the machine age: because James, more than anyone, I think, recognized both the irreducibility of even scientific knowledge to a single set of data or axioms, and also understood that consciousness is rooted not just in abstract reasoning but in a physicality, a sensation of being a person in the world.

I don’t discount the possibility that future AI models can be better historians than any human now living — but I think that’s a multi-decade prospect, and one that will probably require advances in robotics to provide sensory, emotional, and social data to go alongside the textual and visual datasets we currently feed these models on.

All that said — yes, these things can definitely “do” historical research and analysis now, and I am 100% certain that they will improve many aspects of the work historians do to understand the past, especially in the realms of transcription, translation, and image analysis. I find that pretty exciting.


If you’ve read this far, please consider a paid subscription. Reader support is essential for allowing me to write Res Obscura — one of the few places online with ad-free, original longform historical writing. You’ll receive the same weekly posts as free subscribers, plus:

For example, GPT-4o gives “Descritto” instead of “Descritta” in the first line, but either way, the word means “described” (past participle of descrivere). In many cases, the error simply comes down to GPT-4o wanting to impose modern orthography on the early modern text, like “Gentill'homo” (gentleman) being transcribed in the more modern spelling of “Gentil-huomo.”

To craft a robust deep research protocol, could you clarify a few aspects?

1. **Scope of Research Questions**: Are you primarily interested in:
   - The historiographical implications of LLMs in historical research?
   - The cognitive/epistemic behavior of LLMs when confronted with intellectual controversy?
   - The lifecycle and sustainability of research software in historical sciences?
   - Or all of the above?

2. **Comparative Models**: You mentioned Deep Research, OpenAI Operator, Anthropic’s Computer Use, and HuggingFace’s Open Deep Research. Would you like the protocol to:
   - Compare their effectiveness on similar queries?
   - Assess their ability to retrieve, interpret, and generate historiographical analysis?
   - Evaluate their ability to reconstruct historical arguments and perspectives?

3. **Practical Implementation**: How would you like the protocol to be structured?
   - A structured sequence of research questions for each model?
   - A standardized rubric for evaluation (e.g., accuracy, bias, depth of synthesis)?
   - A set of test cases, such as specific historical debates, software projects, or case studies?

4. **Expected Output**: Would you like the protocol to generate:
   - Annotated bibliographies and historiographical assessments?
   - Reconstructions of historiographical debates?
   - Analyses of how these models simulate historical reasoning?

Your input on these points will help shape an effective research protocol for testing these models.

parts:
# Literature Review

## 1. Lifecycle and Sustainability of Research Software in Historical Sciences

**Prior Research and Case Studies:**  Numerous studies in digital humanities and related fields have highlighted concerns about the short lifespan of research software and digital projects relative to the long-term needs of scholarship【13†L116-L124】.  For example, Barats et al. (2020) emphasize the *“inherent tensions between the long-term needs of data preservation and maintenance on the one side, and the short life cycles of data formats, platforms and infrastructures on the other”*【13†L116-L124】.  Tucker (2022) likewise notes that sustainability is a multifaceted challenge – not just technical, but also **financial, institutional, and human** – especially as historians, archaeologists, and linguists increasingly rely on databases, software tools, and digital editions for research【18†L13-L20】.  Tucker proposes defining *“digital sustainability”* as *“the ability to identify the resources needed to keep a digital resource or service delivering value to its intended users”*【19†L19-L23】, underscoring that sustaining software is an active, ongoing process requiring planning and resources.

**Sustainability Frameworks and Methodologies:**  Various frameworks have been proposed to assess or improve research software longevity. For instance, a national report from the Netherlands (2021) on research software sustainability outlines best practices for **software archiving** (preserving source code) and stresses that true sustainability means *being able to run software to reproduce results and reuse it in new contexts*【17†L43-L50】. In practice, this aligns with emerging “FAIR for software” principles (making software **Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable**)【17†L69-L73】. Similarly, the research software engineering community has discussed maturity models. One example is a *“Research Software Levels”* framework inspired by technology readiness levels, which categorizes software by **expected users, distribution, reuse, and support** – from personal one-off scripts (Level 0) up to widely adopted, well-supported tools (Level 4)【22†L31-L39】. Such models help gauge a project’s stage in its lifecycle and what is needed for it to mature sustainably. Moreover, initiatives like the UK’s Software Sustainability Institute and the international **Software Heritage** archive reflect concerted efforts to **institutionalize software preservation** (e.g. by systematically collecting source code for long-term safekeeping)【17†L61-L68】. These frameworks and initiatives indicate a growing awareness of how to evaluate and bolster software longevity, although a universally adopted assessment methodology has yet to crystallize.

**Evidence of the Longevity Problem:**  Case studies in the literature vividly illustrate the risks to unsustained research software. Barats et al. (2020) describe a project (*Calico*, 2006–2009) that developed custom analytical tools for studying online communities. Only a few years after the project’s end, those tools *“are no longer available – be it because of professional mobility of researchers or the lack of funding to maintain the tools”*, a loss which *“directly affects the readability and intelligibility of the results of this research”*【48†L638-L647】. In other words, when project-specific software isn’t preserved or maintained, subsequent scholars may struggle to validate or build upon that research. This phenomenon is not unique: many digital archaeology and corpus linguistics projects have created bespoke software that later became orphaned or unreachable (for instance, due to expired project websites or unarchived code). The Internet Archive and other preservation platforms occasionally capture these project websites, but coverage is uneven. Batist and Roe (2024) provide a quantitative perspective in archaeology: by mining a curated list of archaeology-related software on GitHub, they found that while archaeologists have rapidly adopted open-source platforms like GitHub, the **majority of projects have only 1–3 contributors** and very few enjoy a broad base of maintainers【49†L72-L80】. This suggests many tools are essentially one-person or small-team efforts, which are inherently fragile – if the lead developer moves on, the software’s development (and support for users) often halts. Indeed, Batist and Roe note there is *“little evidence”* that archaeology software development has achieved the kind of decentralized, community-driven sustainability seen in larger open-source projects【49†L72-L80】. 

**Existing Guidance and Gaps:** To mitigate these issues, experts recommend planning for longevity *from a project’s inception*. Smithies et al. (2019), for example, argue that *“digital projects benefit from being planned and executed with their longevity in mind from the start”*【48†L651-L659】 – meaning documentation, modular design, and archiving should be integral to any software developed for research. Some journals now encourage or require authors to deposit software code in repositories and use permanent identifiers (e.g. DOI for code) to ensure future access (SoftwareX and the *Journal of Open Research Software* are notable venues that emphasize these practices). Despite these efforts, **gaps remain**. There is no comprehensive study yet that tracks the full *life cycle* of research software across archaeology, history, and linguistics – from creation to potential abandonment – nor a standard metric to quantify “extant vs. extinct” software projects in these fields. Prior work overlaps with the proposed questions in recognizing the problem and suggesting best practices, but it tends to be either high-level (frameworks, conceptual discussions) or domain-specific (a single field or even single-project case study). A broader empirical assessment of how long research software survives in the wild, what factors lead to successful long-term maintenance (or to project decay), and how scholars can systematically evaluate sustainability is still an open area. In summary, **prior research confirms the importance of software sustainability and offers partial frameworks (multi-dimensional criteria, archiving protocols, etc.)【18†L13-L20】【17†L43-L50】, but a unified methodology to assess and compare software longevity across the historical sciences is not fully developed**. This is a clear gap that the proposed research could fill.

## 2. AI-Driven Research Tools in Literature Review and Historical Research

**Emergence of AI Research Assistants:**  The last couple of years have seen rapid development of AI-driven research tools designed to assist scholars in information gathering and analysis. Notable examples include **OpenAI’s “Deep Research” agent**, which can autonomously browse the web and synthesize information, and **OpenAI’s “Operator”**, an AI agent that performs multi-step tasks like navigating websites or filling forms through a browser-like interface【45†L72-L80】.  Competing platforms have introduced similar capabilities – Anthropic’s **“Computer Use”** API allows its Claude model to control a computer (for example, to open files or click buttons), and Hugging Face’s **“open Deep Research”** is an open-source clone of OpenAI’s agent, developed to democratize this technology【31†L13-L20】. These tools represent an evolution from simple chatbot assistants to more autonomous *research agents* that can conduct searches, read documents, and potentially generate reports with minimal human intervention. Their intended use-cases include automating parts of a systematic literature review (e.g. finding and summarizing relevant sources) and aiding historical research by rapidly retrieving information from archives or databases. Given how new these agents are (most launched in late 2024 or early 2025), **peer-reviewed literature on them is sparse** – current knowledge about their performance comes primarily from tech demos, benchmarks, and early adopters’ experiences. For instance, OpenAI reported benchmark comparisons where its Operator outperformed Anthropic’s tool on certain web tasks【30†L21-L29】【46†L7-L10】, but such results come from internal or industry evaluations rather than independent academic studies.

**Comparative Effectiveness in Literature Reviews:**  While direct studies of these specific agents are just beginning, there is already research examining the use of **large language models (LLMs)** like GPT-3.5/4 in conducting literature reviews. A recent comparative study published in *JMIR AI* (Mostafapour et al., 2024) evaluated literature reviews produced by ChatGPT-4 versus those done by human researchers【27†L181-L189】【27†L193-L201】. The findings are instructive: *“GPT-4 produced an extensive list of [relevant factors] rapidly”*, covering a broad range of points in a fraction of the time a human would need【27†L181-L189】【28†L1-L4】. This suggests that AI can **speed up** the preliminary gathering of literature and highlight key themes very quickly. However, the same study underscores significant **limitations**. The AI-generated review, despite its breadth, required *careful expert evaluation and refinement* – in other words, the researchers found errors and omissions that had to be corrected【28†L1-L4】. The conclusion was that GPT-4 can be *“a valuable tool for conducting preliminary literature reviews by providing a broad overview of topics quickly”*, **but it cannot replace human judgment**【28†L1-L4】. Notably, issues of **accuracy, transparency, and depth** were noted: the AI sometimes lacked nuance in contextual understanding and did not always justify its claims with clear references, whereas the human-led review, though slower, provided a traceable search strategy and critical synthesis of sources【27†L193-L200】【27†L185-L193】. These results align with other early evaluations in STEM fields, where AI tools have been tested for screening articles in systematic reviews. They often show impressive recall (catching many relevant papers) but can also retrieve false positives or miss subtle domain-specific insights, meaning a human expert must remain “in the loop” to ensure quality.

**Autoethnographic and Qualitative Insights:** Beyond outcome-focused comparisons, scholars have also begun reflecting on **how using AI tools changes the research process itself**. One approach has been autoethnography, where researchers document and analyze their personal experience with AI assistance. For example, Schwenke et al. (2023) conducted an autoethnographic study of using ChatGPT during the writing of a bachelor’s thesis【40†L59-L68】. The first author deliberately incorporated ChatGPT into various stages of researching and drafting the thesis, while keeping detailed logs. The study found that *ChatGPT was indeed beneficial for many tasks – brainstorming ideas, suggesting outlines, and even refining prose*【40†L63-L70】. Students could use it as a “more knowledgeable other” to get quick explanations of concepts or generate alternative phrasings. However, **significant limitations emerged**. ChatGPT struggled with providing proper academic references and often could not be trusted to cite reliable sources【40†L63-L71】. The author had to continuously verify the AI’s outputs against the literature (to catch hallucinated facts or misquotes), and ultimately the thesis writing still *“required the learner’s meaningful engagement”* at every step【40†L65-L71】. This autoethnographic evidence echoes what other commentators have warned: current AI tools may *facilitate* research and writing, but they do not inherently understand truth or scholarly significance – they can generate plausible text that hides inaccuracies. Similarly, in the field of human-computer interaction (HCI), a *“trioethnography”* (collaborative autoethnography by three researchers) of using ChatGPT found that while the AI could handle clerical tasks (summarizing transcripts, suggesting related work), the researchers sometimes felt it imposed a sort of “bland” uniform style and could reinforce their preconceived notions, raising questions about how it might subtly shape research narratives (Zhang et al., 2023, as described in a preprint). These qualitative studies provide an *inside look* at the **epistemological implications** of AI assistance: researchers must be mindful of how reliance on an AI might influence which lines of inquiry are pursued or dropped, and how the narrative of research is constructed.

**Epistemological and Methodological Debates:**  The advent of AI-driven research assistants has sparked extensive debate about their role in knowledge production, particularly in historical research where methodology and source interpretation are critical. A special forum in the *American Historical Review* (September 2023) brought together multiple historians to scrutinize *“Artificial Intelligence and the Practice of History.”* This forum – *eight commentaries by different scholars* – represents the most comprehensive discussion to date on AI’s opportunities and pitfalls for historians【53†L1-L4】. Topics included whether an AI could ever function as a historian (*“AI-as-Historian”*), how AI image or text generation might distort our relationship to historical sources, and the importance of understanding the **datasets** behind AI models (echoing Kate Crawford’s call for examining the *“archaeologies of datasets”* that underlie AI systems). The consensus in these essays is cautiously optimistic but warns of serious epistemic challenges. For instance, historians note that generative AI, trained on vast swathes of existing text, *lacks an inherent sense of context or chronology* – it might produce a convincingly written historical narrative that nevertheless mixes eras or introduces anachronisms if the prompt is vague. There is also the issue of **source transparency**: when an AI like ChatGPT asserts a historical “fact” or summary, on what evidence is it based? Unlike a human historian who can cite archival documents or established histories, current AI models do not reliably reveal their sources. This opaque reasoning process has led some scholars to label LLMs as *“stochastic parrots”* – statistical machines stitching together likely sentences without true understanding【42†L63-L71】. Bender et al. (2021) famously used that phrase to critique large language models, and Schryen et al. (2023) note that because these tools *“do not rely on logic, semantic or epistemic models,”* their outputs inherently reflect patterns in existing data rather than novel logical inference【42†L63-L71】. In historical research, this raises concerns that AI tools might inadvertently reinforce existing biases in the historical record (since they’re trained on published texts, which may themselves omit or misrepresent certain perspectives). The *epistemological implication* is that historians must question how knowledge is being filtered or generated by AI – essentially, who (or what) is the “author” of the historical interpretation, and can that interpretation be trusted? These issues are driving new research questions; for example, how might one systematically evaluate the *accuracy and bias* of an AI-generated literature review in history, or what methodologies can ensure that AI tools remain *assistive* without obscuring the researcher’s critical engagement with sources?

**Comparative Effectiveness and Limitations – State of the Art:**  To date, there is **limited formal research directly comparing multiple AI-driven research tools** (like OpenAI’s vs Anthropic’s agents) in a scholarly workflow. Most peer-reviewed work has focused on **one tool at a time** (often ChatGPT) or on general LLM capabilities. The few comparative evaluations (such as Mostafapour et al. on GPT-4 vs human, noted above) show that AI can accelerate certain tasks but at some cost to rigorous completeness【28†L1-L4】. Early **gray literature** and tech reports provide some clues: for example, Hugging Face’s open-source *Open-Deep-Research* agent was benchmarked on the General AI Assistants (GAIA) test, approaching the performance of OpenAI’s proprietary agent【31†L3-L7】. These benchmarks typically measure how well the AI agent finds correct information or completes web-based tasks. However, academic researchers are only beginning to ask higher-level questions such as: *Do AI literature agents actually find **better** sources or insights that a human might miss, or do they just find them faster?* And *how do errors introduced by AI (e.g. a hallucinated citation) propagate into a researcher’s work if not caught?* There is also the matter of **user experience** – a systematic literature review process has well-established protocols (search strings, inclusion/exclusion criteria, quality appraisal of sources). Integrating an AI agent into this process might require new methodologies or frameworks. A recent perspective by Schryen et al. (2023) suggests viewing generative AI through an *“epistemological lens”* in the context of literature reviews, mapping which steps of knowledge-building the AI can support and which steps remain inherently human-led【42†L21-L28】【42†L63-L71】. They conclude that while AI tools can aid in idea generation and even potentially reveal connections between literatures, the *innovation* in research still largely comes from human scholars – partly because AI lacks intentionality and partly because of the risk of false or unoriginal outputs【42†L63-L71】. 

**Summary of Overlap and Gaps:**  In summary, **prior work has begun to explore the effectiveness, limitations, and epistemic issues of AI-driven research tools, but it only partially overlaps with the proposed research questions**. We have evidence that using AI (especially LLMs like ChatGPT) in literature reviews can be beneficial for speed and breadth, yet problematic in accuracy and reasoning transparency【28†L1-L4】【40†L63-L71】. We also have a growing body of commentary (both peer-reviewed and gray literature) raising theoretical concerns about how these tools might alter research practices and the construction of knowledge【53†L1-L4】【42†L63-L71】. However, **significant gaps remain**. There is hardly any peer-reviewed study comparing different AI agents (OpenAI vs Anthropic vs open-source) in a *systematic literature review context* – an area the proposed work could pioneer. Likewise, in historical research, beyond essays and thought pieces, we lack empirical studies on using AI tools in real historical inquiries (for instance, an experiment where historians use an AI agent to assist in primary source analysis, and the outcomes are evaluated). The *autoethnographic* studies so far focus on researchers’ experiences in general academic writing; none, to our knowledge, have been published on autoethnography of AI use specifically in **historical methodology** or historiography. This means the deeper *epistemological implications* – how AI assistance might influence a historian’s interpretative decisions or a corpus linguist’s analytical lens – are still largely speculative. The AHR forum signals that the community is aware of these questions【53†L1-L4】, but it also makes clear that we are at the beginning of understanding them. In essence, prior work provides a foundation (demonstrating some pros/cons of AI tools and voicing concerns) but does not yet offer definitive answers or comprehensive comparative evaluations. **The proposed research would therefore directly address these open gaps**: it would overlap with prior studies in motivation (improving software sustainability; critically assessing AI in research) while breaking new ground in systematically measuring research software longevity and rigorously evaluating AI-driven research assistants in practice. By doing so, it aims to contribute both practical frameworks (for assessing software lifespan and AI tool efficacy) and theoretical insight (into the evolving epistemology of AI-augmented scholarship). 

**Sources:**

- Barats, C., et al. (2020). *“Fading Away... The challenge of sustainability in digital studies.”* **Digital Humanities Quarterly, 14(3)** – Highlights tension between short software lifecycles and long-term research needs【13†L116-L124】.

- Tucker, J. (2022). *“Facing the challenge of digital sustainability as humanities researchers.”* **Journal of the British Academy, 10** – Proposes multifaceted definition of digital sustainability (technological, financial, environmental, human)【18†L13-L20】【19†L19-L23】.

- LCRDM Task Group (2021). *“Research software sustainability in the Netherlands: Current practices and recommendations.”* – Defines sustainability in terms of **archiving, reproducibility and reuse** of software【17†L43-L50】; advocates national support and archives like **Software Heritage**【17†L61-L68】.

- Batist, Z. & Roe, J. (2024). *“Open archaeology, open source? Collaborative practices in an emerging community of archaeological software engineers.”* **Internet Archaeology, 67** – Analyzes 25 years of archaeology software on GitHub; finds most projects have very few contributors (1–3), implying limited community sustainability【49†L72-L80】.

- Barats, C., et al. (2020). *DHQ 14(3)* – Case study of the **Calico project** where custom research tools became unavailable a few years post-project due to lack of maintenance, undermining result reproducibility【48†L638-L647】.

- Mostafapour, M., et al. (2024). *“Evaluating Literature Reviews Conducted by Humans Versus ChatGPT: Comparative Study.”* **JMIR AI, 1(1)** – Found GPT-4 can quickly draft a broad literature review but with errors; human oversight is necessary for accuracy and depth【28†L1-L4】.

- Schwenke, N., et al. (2023). *“Chatbot-supported Thesis Writing: An Autoethnographic Report.”* (Preprint) – Documents a student’s extensive use of ChatGPT in writing a thesis. ChatGPT helped with brainstorming and editing but **struggled with reliable referencing**, requiring continuous verification by the student【40†L63-L71】.

- Schryen, G., et al. (2023). *“Adopting Generative AI for Literature Reviews: An Epistemological Perspective.”* (Conference paper) – Discusses how LLMs (ChatGPT, Bard) might support literature review processes. Notes that LLMs can improve writing productivity (communication) but true **knowledge innovation** still depends on human researchers, given that LLMs generate text based on past data (the “stochastic parrot” critique)【42†L63-L71】.

- American Historical Review (Sept 2023). *“Artificial Intelligence and the Practice of History: A Forum.”* – A collection of essays by historians on AI’s role in research and teaching. It is described as *“the fullest discussion currently available on the implications and opportunities of AI for historians”*【53†L1-L4】, covering issues like AI’s handling of historical sources, biases in training data, and the concept of AI as a historian. (Multiple contributors, e.g., B. Schmidt on representation learning, K. Crawford on datasets, J. Sternfeld on “AI-as-Historian”). *(Gray literature summary available via Royal Historical Society blog.)*

- OpenAI (2025) – *Operator* and *Deep Research* tool announcements. *(Tech news)* OpenAI’s **Operator** agent (with the *“Computer-Using Agent”* model) can execute web-based tasks autonomously【45†L72-L80】. This was benchmarked against Anthropic’s **Computer Use** functionality and other agents; early tests show such agents can navigate websites and gather info, but formal academic evaluation of their research reliability is still pending【30†L21-L29】.

- Additional resources on software sustainability and digital project preservation in humanities, including: Flanders & Munoz (2012) on *“sustainable humanities computing”*, the **Software Sustainability Institute (UK)** blogs (e.g., examples of archaeology software being made open-source【2†L6-L13】), and studies of **link rot** in scholarly outputs (e.g., Klein et al. 2014 on reference rot in publications). *(These provide context on why sustainability frameworks are needed, though not directly cited above.)*

metadata.text: This paper emphasizes the need to think about sustainability as a key element of digital studies and digital hermeneutics. It addresses the inherent tensions between the long-term needs of data preservation and maintenance on the one side, and the short life cycles of the data formats, platforms and infrastructures on the other side. Challenges are not limited to the technical maintenance of software, tools and data, but also apply to the wider institutional contexts, epistemic traditions and social practices in which the doing of research in social sciences and humanities are embedded. We explore these tensions at several levels, temporalities and key stages in research –

metadata.text: The Recommendations for Research Software Sustainability in the Netherlands addresses the topics of software archiving (the storage of source code) and also software sustainability, which also covers the aspects of being able to run software to reproduce results, and the reuse of software in new contexts to produce new results (Reproducibility & Replicability). The results are addressed towards various stakeholders in the science system. In recent months, Gerard Coen (Project lead Software Sustainability at DANS) has been part of an LCRDM Task Group collaborating to produce the work.

metadata.title: JMIR AI - Evaluating Literature Reviews Conducted by Humans Versus ChatGPT: Comparative Study
metadata.text: Background: With the rapid evolution of artificial intelligence (AI), particularly large language models (LLMs) such as ChatGPT-4 (OpenAI), there is an increasing interest in their potential to assist in scholarly tasks, including conducting literature reviews. However, the efficacy of AI-generated reviews compared with traditional human-led approaches remains underexplored.

metadata.title: JMIR AI - Evaluating Literature Reviews Conducted by Humans Versus ChatGPT: Comparative Study
metadata.text: patients in medicolegal contexts. One review used GPT-4, last updated in September 2021, and the other was conducted by human researchers. The human review involved a comprehensive literature search using medical subject headings and keywords in Ovid MEDLINE, followed by a thematic analysis of the literature to synthesize information from selected articles. The AI-generated review used a new prompt engineering approach, using iterative and sequential prompts to generate results. Comparative analysis was based on qualitative measures such as accuracy, response time, consistency, breadth and depth of knowledge, contextual understanding, and transparency.

metadata.title: [2311.10729] Chatbot-supported Thesis Writing: An Autoethnographic Report
metadata.text: first author was asked to write his bachelor's thesis exploiting ChatGPT. For tracing the impact of ChatGPT, methodically an autoethnographic approach was used. First, all considerations on the potential use of ChatGPT were documented in logs and secondly, all ChatGPT chats were logged. Both logs and chat histories were analyzed and are presented along to the recommendations for students regarding the use of ChatGPT suggested by Gimpel et al. (2023). In conclusion, ChatGPT is beneficial in thesis writing during various activities, such as brainstorming, structuring and text revision. However, there arise limitations, e.g., in referencing. Thus, ChatGPT requires a continuous validation of the outcomes generated fostering learning. Currently, ChatGPT is

metadata.title:
DHQ: Digital Humanities Quarterly: Fading Away... The challenge of sustainability in
               digital studies
metadata.text: This paper emphasizes the need to think about sustainability as a key element of digital studies and digital hermeneutics. It addresses the inherent tensions between the long-term needs of data preservation and maintenance on the one side, and the short life cycles of the data formats, platforms and infrastructures on the other side. Challenges are not limited to the technical maintenance of software, tools and data, but also apply to the wider institutional contexts, epistemic traditions and social practices in which the doing of research in social sciences and humanities are embedded. We explore these tensions at several levels, temporalities and key stages in research –

view of the current landscape as well as thoughts for the future of digital research for scholars in the humanities. It considers four aspects of sustainability (technological, financial, environmental and ‘human’), and offers a new working definition for digital sustainability in this context. This centres on sustainability not just as a technical concern but as a multifaceted activity within which humanities researchers can play a crucial role.
definition of sustainability (at p. 12) is: ‘The ability to identify the resources needed to keep a digital resource or service delivering value to the users it is intended to serve.’

metadata.title: LCRDM Task Group publishes report Research Software Sustainability in the Netherlands - DANS
metadata.text: The Recommendations for Research Software Sustainability in the Netherlands addresses the topics of software archiving (the storage of source code) and also software sustainability, which also covers the aspects of being able to run software to reproduce results, and the reuse of software in new contexts to produce new results (Reproducibility & Replicability). The results are addressed towards various stakeholders in the science system. In recent months, Gerard Coen (Project lead Software Sustainability at DANS) has been part of an LCRDM Task Group collaborating to produce the work.

metadata.title: OpenAI’s Operator Automates Online Tasks with a New AI Agent
metadata.text: What’s new: Operator automates online actions like buying goods, booking tickets and completing forms by navigating websites in a browser-like environment within ChatGPT. It’s available on desktops as a research preview for subscribers to ChatGPT Pro ($200 per month). OpenAI promises broader availability to come as well as API access to the underlying model and improved ability to coordinate multi-step tasks like scheduling meetings across calendars from different vendors.

content_references.title: JMIR AI - Evaluating Literature Reviews Conducted by Humans Versus ChatGPT: Comparative Study
content_references.snippet: Background: With the rapid evolution of artificial intelligence (AI), particularly large language models (LLMs) such as ChatGPT-4 (OpenAI), there is an increasing interest in their potential to assist in scholarly tasks, including conducting literature reviews. However, the efficacy of AI-generated reviews compared with traditional human-led approaches remains underexplored.

content_references.title: JMIR AI - Evaluating Literature Reviews Conducted by Humans Versus ChatGPT: Comparative Study
content_references.snippet: patients in medicolegal contexts. One review used GPT-4, last updated in September 2021, and the other was conducted by human researchers. The human review involved a comprehensive literature search using medical subject headings and keywords in Ovid MEDLINE, followed by a thematic analysis of the literature to synthesize information from selected articles. The AI-generated review used a new prompt engineering approach, using iterative and sequential prompts to generate results. Comparative analysis was based on qualitative measures such as accuracy, response time, consistency, breadth and depth of knowledge, contextual understanding, and transparency.

content_references.title:
DHQ: Digital Humanities Quarterly: Fading Away... The challenge of sustainability in
               digital studies
content_references.snippet: This paper emphasizes the need to think about sustainability as a key element of digital studies and digital hermeneutics. It addresses the inherent tensions between the long-term needs of data preservation and maintenance on the one side, and the short life cycles of the data formats, platforms and infrastructures on the other side. Challenges are not limited to the technical maintenance of software, tools and data, but also apply to the wider institutional contexts, epistemic traditions and social practices in which the doing of research in social sciences and humanities are embedded. We explore these tensions at several levels, temporalities and key stages in research –

view of the current landscape as well as thoughts for the future of digital research for scholars in the humanities. It considers four aspects of sustainability (technological, financial, environmental and ‘human’), and offers a new working definition for digital sustainability in this context. This centres on sustainability not just as a technical concern but as a multifaceted activity within which humanities researchers can play a crucial role.
definition of sustainability (at p. 12) is: ‘The ability to identify the resources needed to keep a digital resource or service delivering value to the users it is intended to serve.’
